newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria parliament sets up state investment bank.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria parliament sets up state investment bank.

text.p: Bulgaria's parliament on Wednesday approved a law establishing a State Bank for Investment and Development (SBID) to support small- and medium-sized firms.
The bank is expected to have equity capital of two billion levs, of which 51 percent will be held by the state represented by the government.
Under the law, the remaining 49 percent will be offered to state institutions and enterprises and foreign companies.
A quarter of Bulgaria's banks are in receivership and the central bank has yet to decide which banks to close and which to stabilise.
Many state enterprises have had their accounts blocked by the closures. Funds in the new bank are expected to be guaranteed by the state.

The bank is expected to start operating in six months after a 500 million lev upfront equity payment. The remaining payments will be made in three 500 million lev installments over the next six years.
The bank's operation will include crediting, accumulation of deposits, dealing in government securities and fund mangement deals, the law says.
Under the law, the central bank is expected to refinance SBID up to the amount of its own capital.
SBID's initial capital will come from the Bulgarian Economic Chamber, of which state enterprises are members. -- Sofia Newsroom, 359-2-84561
